Description.val:
[P5 / 1V045 Access Systems & Subsystems]: Cryptologic Carry-On Equipment: The Cryptologic Carry-On-Program (CCOP) procures state-of-the-art, commercial off-the-shelf Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) equipment (hardware and software) in response to combatant commander requirements for a quick-reaction surface, subsurface, and airborne cryptologic carry-on capability.  The equipment is procured in accordance with requirements detailed in the shipboard Information Warfare / Cryptologic System Operational Requirements Document and specific execution year fleet requirements.  These requirements are defined by the Signals of Interest (SOI) Integrated Product Team (IPT), in concert with Shipboard Signals Exploitation Space (SSES) programs (includes Ship's Signal Exploitation Equipment Family of Systems) to ensure synergy and seamless transition to permanently installed systems.  The IPT meets to determine which SOIs/Targets on the SOI list need to be addressed.  Due to a continually changing threat environment, detailed requirements are dynamic and equipment procured varies each year by quantity and type.  Equipment suites can be configured for many targets and tasking.  Target specific subsystems can either operate as stand-alone within the cryptologic spaces or as an add-on to existing equipment.  Hardware procurements includes: receivers, recorders, tactical computers and related peripherals, antennas, electronic-warfare support measures systems, precision geolocation equipment, advanced signal and search equipment including spectrum analyzers and associated portable special intelligence communications equipment.  CCOP equipment is installed as an augment to cryptologic capabilities on subsurface, surface, and air platforms.  There are approximately 124 cryptologic capable surface ships and shore sites in the current Navy inventory.  Each of these are potential users of this carry-on equipment, as are subsurface and air platforms.  The temporary installation of equipment is coordinated through fleet electronic support personnel.  A primary system in inventory is the Carry On Radio Spectrum Analysis & Intelligence Reporting (CORSAIR) system.  Funds continue to procure CORSAIR core architecture system upgrades to provide additional affordable functionality to the combatant commands.  Additional signal acquisition equipment to address specific combatant command requirements include such systems as Digital Receiver Technology (DRT), Hostile forces Integrated Targeting Service (HITS), Maritime Toxic Pen (MTP), TURBULENTWAVE / TURBULENTWIND / TURBULENTSAIL / BLUESTREAM servers, RED FALCON, FIREFLY, TEASTAR, Generic Area Limitations Environment (GALE)-Lite, and OWN FORCE MONITORING equipment.  This line also supports the procurement of STALLION hardware for CCOP team training.

[P5 / [USFFC ID] GDX6D - Global Signal Analysis Equipment]: Funds for Global Signals Analysis Laboratory (GSAL) program supports procurement to facilitate the data handling subsystem accredited by National Security Agency (NSA). The GSAL program, under project name CLASSIC SENSEI, provides for the timely analysis of data derived from maritime Information Warfare (IW) operations. This architecture known as LABLINK provides advanced manipulation, forwarding, and exchanges of data while providing connectivity with collaborating military, national, and international partners throughout the intelligence community. Signals Analysis Laboratories (SAL) are co-located with Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOC) and other Fleet concentrations areas to perform high priority theater-level analysis and processing. The GSAL program office equips the eight (8) SAL's with advanced signals analysis capabilities in order to accomplish the in-depth signals analysis that is required to effectively address processing and exploitation requirements in support of both maritime tactical and national strategic IW objectives. Funding sustains SAL integration for security and new technology requirements to facilitate highly technical analysis in a highly diverse, constantly changing, and contested electromagnetic environment. SALs are integral components of the Tech Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) Revitalization initiatives that provide a collaborative enterprise. Global Signal Analysis Equipment (GSAL) quantity is based on updating  one (1) of eight (8) signals analysis labs and are not representative of any single systems or end items.

[P5 / [USFFC ID] Global Signal Analysis Laboratory (GSAL)]: Funds for Global Signals Analysis Laboratory (GSAL) program supports procurement to facilitate the data handling subsystem accredited by National Security Agency (NSA). The GSAL program, under project name CLASSIC SENSEI, provides for the timely analysis of data derived from maritime Information Warfare (IW) operations. This architecture known as LABLINK provides advanced manipulation, forwarding, and exchanges of data while providing connectivity with collaborating military, national, and international partners throughout the intelligence community. Signals Analysis Laboratories (SAL) are co-located with Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOC) and other Fleet concentrations areas to perform high priority theater-level analysis and processing. The GSAL program office equips the eight (8) SAL's with advanced signals analysis capabilities in order to accomplish the in-depth signals analysis that is required to effectively address processing and exploitation requirements in support of both maritime tactical and national strategic IW objectives. Funding sustains SAL integration for security and new technology requirements to facilitate highly technical analysis in a highly diverse, constantly changing, and contested electromagnetic environment. SALs are integral components of the Tech Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) Revitalization initiatives that provide a collaborative enterprise. FY21 funding provided for Global Signal Analysis Equipment (GSAL) quantity is based on updating one (1) of eight (8) signals analysis labs and are not representative of any single systems or end items.

[P5 / [USFFC ID] GDX6D - System Integration and Installation of Hardware]: This effort upgraded the Navy Tactical Data Network hardware at the Unified Atlantic Region Network Operations Center. The hardware upgrade will enable additional ships (up to 40+) to connect to the Fleet Data Distribution Server.   Additionally, this effort provided with two fundamental capabilities that allow for rapid response to emergent threats: 
1) Capability to quickly and remotely (from shore or ship) re-task collection systems based on mission and operational area 
2) Capability to get the collected data products to shore facilities for analysis by the Intelligence Community in real time, advancing the capabilities of systems like SSEE Inc. F and CCOP's CORSAIR systems. 

The Navy Information Warfare Center Pacific (NIWC-PAC) has a critical role by installing, configuring, and maintaining servers like Fleet Data Distribution System (FDDS), Navy Data Distribution System (NDDS), PLUTO and SAND and real time collection systems such as BLUESTREAM on both JWICS and NSANet. 

The effort keeps NIWC at the forefront of leveraging emerging infrastructure like MACHINESHOP and Amazon Commercial Cloud Service (C2S). These servers provide critical infrastructure without the use of multiple hardware chassis, push/pull the collection data off a collection systems and route that data to the Intelligence Community (IC) where the data can be analyzed while the ship that collected the information is still deployed. 

The DSO effort will be critical going forward as we maintain our current efforts as well as develop future systems such as NTDN 2.0 and the all-encompassing CRC DASHBOARD.

[P5 / [USFFC ID] System Integration & Installation of Hardware (FIOC)]: Funds are required for purchasing and maintaining life cycle support for command and control systems connected to Sensitive Compartmented Information (SCI) networks as well as to develop and maintain a common baseline of analytical intelligence software tools. This capability directly supports Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOCs) areas as defined in the operational strategy (OPSTRAT). Each FIOC, who is co-located with National Security Agency (NSA) Cryptologic Centers, is charged with providing regionally focused Information Operation (IO) and Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) support to Fleet Commanders.

[P5 / [USFFC ID] EW Fleet Synthethic Trainer Consolidation]: Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) / Counter Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C-ISR) initiative addresses the lack of realistic SIGINT / C-ISR during exercises supporting the Fleet Training Continuum (FTC). Addresses critical requirements for SIGINT and C-ISR in Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) required in preparing Intelligence personnel/teams for forward deployed operations. This effort provides the ability to exercise shipboard Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS/SCI) capabilities in an environment not subject to counter-detection. Improves staff operational planning and tactical decision making combined with improvements to overall Intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the Optimized-Fleet Response Plan (O-FRP). Supports assured Command/Control (C2) and Cyber Situational Awareness/Cyber Defense and Enhanced Naval Network Environment (NNE) Information Dominance Integrated Process Capabilities Lists (IPCLs). Builds upon General Services (GENSER) Navy Continuous Training Environment (NCTE) to expand the existing GENSER NCTE with above GENSER capabilities to include TS-SCI FST architecture/capabilities. Provides for architecture, capabilities and scenario build-out as well as required life-cycle management. This capability will enhance individual units and Strike Groups in exercising integrated kinetic and non-kinetic capabilities, to include operations/intelligence fusion required for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW).

[P5 / [USFFC ID] EW Fleet Synthethic Trainer Consolidation]: Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) Signals Intelligence (SIGINT) / Counter Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C-ISR) initiative addresses the lack of realistic SIGINT / C-ISR during exercises supporting the Fleet Training Continuum (FTC). Addresses critical requirements for SIGINT and C-ISR in Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) required in preparing Intelligence personnel/teams for forward deployed operations. This effort provides the ability to exercise shipboard Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS/SCI) capabilities in an environment not subject to counter-detection. Improves staff operational planning and tactical decision making combined with improvements to overall Intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the Optimized-Fleet Response Plan (O-FRP). Supports assured Command/Control (C2) and Cyber Situational Awareness/Cyber Defense and Enhanced Naval Network Environment (NNE) Information Dominance Integrated Process Capabilities Lists (IPCLs). Builds upon General Services (GENSER) Navy Continuous Training Environment (NCTE) to expand the existing GENSER NCTE with above GENSER capabilities to include TS-SCI FST architecture/capabilities. Provides for architecture, capabilities and scenario build-out as well as required life-cycle management. This capability will enhance individual units and Strike Groups in exercising integrated kinetic and non-kinetic capabilities, to include operations/intelligence fusion required for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW).

[P5 / [USFFC N7] Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) SIGINT / C-ISR]: Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) Signals Intelligence (SIGINT)/Counter Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (C-ISR) initiative addresses the lack of realistic SIGINT/C-ISR during exercises supporting the Fleet Training Continuum (FTC). This effort provides the capability to exercise shipboard Top Secret Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS SCI) capabilities by expanding upon General Service (GENSER) Navy Continuous Training Environment (NCTE) capabilities to add above GENSER architecture/capabilities. Provides architecture, systems and required life cycle management to improve staff operational planning and tactical decision making, and overall intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the Optimized Fleet Response Plan (O FRP). This capability will enhance individual units and strike groups in exercising integrated kinetic and non kinetic capabilities to include operations/intelligence fusion required for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in SIGINT, Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW), and cyberspace operations. Addresses critical requirements for SIGINT and C-ISR in FST required in preparing Intelligence personnel/teams for forward deployed operations. Provides systems with the ability to exercise shipboard TS SCI capabilities in an environment not subject to counter detection. Improves staff operational planning and tactical decision making and overall Intelligence team readiness and certification throughout the O FRP and supports Assured Command and Control (C2) and Cyber Situational Awareness/Cyber Defense and Enhanced Naval Network Environment (NNE) Information Dominance Integrated Prioritized Capabilities Lists (IPCLs).

[P5 / [USFFC N7] Tier 1 TS/SCI NCTE & VOIP Procurement & Installation]: Funds for procurement of a Tier 1 Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS/SCI) Navy Continuous Training Environment (NCTE) node.  No node was procured in FY20.  Funding will also procure two (2) Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) systems. No VOIPs were procured in FY20.

[P5 / [USFFC N7] Tier 1 Life Cycle Management (LCM)]: Funding for life cycle technical refresh for node equipment. Life Cycle technical refresh must be completed at least once every three (3) years for the life of the node.

[P5 / [USFFC N7] SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Permanent Shipboard Installation]: Funding in support of permanent shipboard installations that provide capability for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in Signals Intelligence (SIGINT), Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW), and cyberspace operations. FY21 funding allows for 19 permanent shipboard installations.

[P5 / [USFFC N7] SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Life Cycle Management (LCM)]: Funds provide life cycle maintenance and support for shipboard installed equipment/systems. Unit cost reduction achieved through economies of scale and comparisons with technical refresh efforts for other systems.

[P5 / [USFFC N7] Fleet Training Wholeness (FTW)]: Funding for installation support for 19 permanent shipboards systems, technical refresh of 42 interim capability Portable Embarkation Kits (PEKs) on ships awaiting permanent equipment installation, and  fluctuations in the locations of those installations (i.e., increased travel requirement/costs for overseas locations (e.g., Spain, Japan).

Justification.val:
FY21 funds will continue to satisfy signals exploitation capability gaps as determined by the Cryptologic Carry-on Program (CCOP) Signals of Interest (SOI) Integrated Product Team (IPT) and Fleet Signals Development Working Group (FSDWG) and provide supplemental capability to host Signals Intelligence systems.  Recommended procurements best suited to address identified gaps include: Digital Receiver Technology (DRT), Hostile forces Integrated Targeting Service (HITS), Maritime Toxic Pen (MTP), TURBULENTWAVE / TURBULENTWIND / TURBULENTSAIL, BLUESTREAM servers, RED FALCON, TEAPARTY/TEALEAF, and Generic Area Limitations Environment (GALE)-Lite, OWN FORCE MONITORING equipment, Carry On Radio Spectrum Analysis & Intelligence Reporting (CORSAIR), as well as Adaptive Mission Packages. 

FY21 increase ($0.553K) to the Cryptologic Carry-on Program (CCOP) is due to an additional procurement (39 in total in FY21 as compared to 38 in FY20) and associated production support costs. FY21 funds will continue to satisfy signals exploitation capability gaps as determined by the CCOP Signals of Interest (SOI) Integrated Product Team (IPT) and Fleet Signals Development Working Group (FSDWG) and provide supplemental capability to host Signals Intelligence systems.  Recommended procurements best suited to address identified gaps include: Digital Receiver Technology (DRT), Hostile forces Integrated Targeting Service (HITS), Maritime Toxic Pen (MTP), TURBULENTWAVE / TURBULENTWIND / TURBULENTSAIL, BLUESTREAM servers, RED FALCON, TEAPARTY/TEALEAF, and Generic Area Limitations Environment (GALE)-Lite, OWN FORCE MONITORING equipment, Carry On Radio Spectrum Analysis & Intelligence Reporting (CORSAIR), as well as Adaptive Mission Packages.

FY21 Global Signal Analysis Laboratory (GSAL) decrease ($0.006M) due to current market cost of procure equipment items. Funding sustains Signals Analysis Laboratories (SAL) integration for security and new technology requirements that facilitate technical analysis in diverse and contested electromagnetic environments. SALs are integral components of the Tech Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) Revitalization initiatives.  

FY21 System Integration & Installation of Hardware (FIOC) decrease ($0.015M) due to current market price for maintaining life cycle support for command and control systems connected to Sensitive Compartmented Information (SCI) networks. Funds also utilized to develop and maintain a common baseline of analytical intelligence software tools, commercial software licenses and locality of FIOCs.

FY21 EW Fleet Synthetic Trainer Consolidation increase ($0.403M) due to further development into Stallion Signal Intelligence scenarios at Center for Information Dominance Cryptologic "C" and "F" schools, as well as the continuum of Navy Continuous Training Environment (NCTE) Fleet Synthetic Training (FST) events. This funding further supports continued Stallion tool development, regression testing, accreditation documentation, and system engineering support at Naval Information Forces Command.

FY21 Tier 1 TS/SCI NCTE & VOIP Procurement & Installation increase ($1.020M) due to procurement of a Tier 1 Top Secret(TS)/SCI NCTE node and two (2) Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) systems.  

FY21 Tier 1 Life Cycle Management (LCM) increase ($0.069M) due to increased life cycle technical refresh cost for node equipment. Life cycle technical refresh must be completed every three (3) years for the life of the node.

FY21 SIGINT / Counter Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (C-ISR) Systems - Permanent Shipboard Installation increase ($0.114M) due increase in shipboard installations that provide capability for comprehensive maritime operations and operational proficiency in SIGINT, Electromagnetic Maneuver Warfare (EMW), and cyberspace operations. 

FY21 SIGINT / C-ISR Systems - Life Cycle Management (LCM) increase ($0.003M) due to unit cost. As the number of shipboard installations increase, the life cycle maintenance cost per unit is decreasing due to increased volume discount pricing. 

FY21 Fleet Training Wholeness (FTW) increase ($0.675M) due to increase in installation support for permanent shipboards systems, technical refresh of interim capability Portable Embarkation Kits (PEKs), and fluctuations in the locations of installations.

Remarks.val: [Hardware] FY20 to FY21 decrease is due to amount of commercial software licenses and locality of Fleet Information Operations Centers (FIOCs).
